page.title: 17Home life:Hutton & Gillamoor
page.content: The working day begins about 7 o'clock Bacon and eggs are no longer usual for breakfast, except at week-ends.Workers drive away. The school buses leave at 8.30a.m. taking small children to Kirkbymoorside,and others to Nawton.On the farms,'10 o'clocks' or'allowances' are mid-morning snacks. The mid-day meal, now not usually the main meal , is referred to,as'lunch' by all except the children, who still call it the more traditional 'dinner-time'. Sunday lunch, however, is still roast meat Yorkshire pudding, and vegatables. The evening meal, usually called 'tea',may be sandwiches and cakes,or a 3 course meal.About 60% of people eat only trad -itional English food. Fish and chips or convenience foods are rarely eaten. Cooking is done on oil, electric or coal stoves. Most homes have a deep- freezer. Cakes and jams are homemade.
